DEBATING IN A SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY.
llE debate has been a cherished institution in the University of North
Carolina from its earliest days. It has the impulse of past achievement and
the st•mulus of tradition. But to realize its status in the university some
knowledge is necessary of two institutions that have fostered and cherished it,
the Dialectic and Philanthropic literary societies." These societies are almost coeval with the university itself, their life dating from the year 1795.
The existence of two such societies in the same college with like interests
and aims led necessarily to friendly rivalry. This has taken the form of intersociety debates. At present the "society stipulations" provide for a series of
three contests yearly, a fieshman -sophomore, a sophomore-junior, and a juniorsenior intersociety debate. Representatives for these debates are elected, but
merit, not politics, is the arbiter. The stimulus and benefit arising from this
graded system is obvious. The next step was to combine and seek a foreign
foe. In 1897 a series of three intercollegiate debates was arranged with the
conUniversity of Georgia, and the arrangement renewed in 1900 for a similar

for affirmative and negative is more satisfactory because it opens play for
originality and improvisation, and kindles the fire of expectation in the audience, in short, developes the spirit of debate.
By a series of interclass and intersociety preliminary contests, the intercollegiate representative team thrice faces scrub teams that are only "second best"
to themselves. The debater who has fought his way up from "fresh-soph" to
junior-senior and through scrub contests to university representative is no
-mean antagonist. He has survived as the fittest.
How does this work come in touch with other lines of endeavor in the university? In several ways. First, the committee that decides these contests is
composed of members of the faculty of the university; the coaches that drill the
debaters into form are members of the faculty. such as the professors of logic,
of economics, of social science, of law (as the query may demand), of English,
of expression, of logic, and former debaters who have been through the mill
and won their laurels. Furthermore, the speeches thus prepared are accepted
as theses by the departments they most appropriately fall under; e. g., a speech
thus made on the trust problem could be offered as a graduating thesis in the
department of economics.
Second, it is evident that these debates are educative both for the individual participating and the student audience, but the influence does not stop

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

they seemed to know their subject as well, and up to the last speech by the
negative they were probably in the lead. In the opinion of some people in the
audience the speeches of the two Hopkins men did not fit together as well as
those of their opponents, which may have had some effect on the decision. At
all events, our team of raw men debating against men whose training is sketched
In .the preceding article put up a fight that was creditable enough to inspire
Pride in every Hopkins son.
To be more specific, our first speaker, Harry Plaggemeyer, was, as usual,
very effective; he had with him that earnest, convincing manner that the critic
of the last inter-class debate has already noted. Plaggemeyer is so true in his
method that he would almost convince a judge if he recited one of "Mother
Goose's" rhymes. Plaggemeyer's first speech was, too, unutterably slow, and
was only redeemed by the speaker's forensic skill. His speech had point to it,
but it lacked vigor and attractiveness. Plaggemeyer seemed to feel this, and
was not nearly so effective as in the second speech, when he warmed up to his
subject and made one of the best speeches of the evening.
Mr. Stern made the first speech for the negative. Stern is not an orator,
hut he says what he has to say in a clear-cut, intelligent manner, that carries
conviction wherever it is heard. This only applies to his first address. His
second speech would only have done justice to a third-rate demagogue. It is
Incomprehensible how a man of Mr. Stern's intelligence could have written so
Poor a speech. However, Stern's splendid first speech did much to give victory
to the negative.
Stone for Hopkins was clever and, evidently, had considerable knowledge
of his subject. Both of his speeches seemed to be extemporaneous, and were,
consequently, somewhat disjointed. Stone made some of his opponent's arguments appear so absurd and self-contradictory that they did not even attempt to
answer him. Stone's rebuttal was admirable, and if any man at Hopkins has a
greater power of satire, and knows how to get at the salient points of an argument better than Stone, he has not been heard at McCoy Hall for a few years.
By far the best speaker of the evening was Williams. who closed the debate for North Carolina. His first speech fitted beautifully with his colleague's.
It was a very interesting argument on "How the Trust Promotes Foreign
Trade." His second speech, the last of the evening, was the best of the evening.
In it, Williams won the debate for North Carolina. Before that speech it
seemed to the writer that Hopkins had the better of the discussion, but after it
the judges could have only made one decision and they did.
Both Stone and Plaggemeyer worked hard and spoke well, and it is quite
Probable that with a few more weeks preparation there would have been a differ
ent story to tell. But as a gentleman who had much to do with the debate said:
"Hopkins didn't lose by much" This defeat at our first inter-collegiate debate
should not discourage us, because there was nothing discouraging in our work.
It would have been more discouraging to win a poor debate. A defeat like this
one will only nerve us on to a victory over North Carolina and other colleges,
(Columbia and Brown, probably,) next year. That is, if we have the true
Hopkins spirit."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
A TALK WITH DR. PEARSONS.

R. D. K. PEARSONS is an aged Chicago philanthropist who has
given a great deal of money to Western colleges. His opinions on
educational methods are, therefore, of some weight. They are also
rather curious, when we remember that this is the twentieth century.
Here are some extracts from an interview given by Dr. Pearsons to some
newspaper men in Chicago:
(Sfieaking of Football.)
"It's a humbug. If I had a boy going to college and he played football or
baseball I would whip him. Down with them both! They are fads and we, in
our educational practices get back to our first principles. They say football
and baseball are good exercise for muscular development; why, if you really
want to develop a boy's muscles put him to sawing wood or raising potatoes
and watch his muscles grow. I never played football or baseball.
"As for the college fads, they are bad, bad. The regular college curri
culum is the thing to follow, and when students go a chasing after this thing
and that thing they tumble over. There are too many fads, and one of the
worst is this habit of sending girls away to schools where tuition alone amounts
to several hundred dollars a year. There is no use of paying more than $2 a
week for board and $150 should carry any young man or young woman through
college for a year.
"They are through raising the kind of boys in the East that made this
country what it is, and the type of men are growing up in the West that made
New England famous 100 years ago. Eastern boys are effeminate. They are
being reared in too much luxury and have not that sturdiness that characterizes
the boy of the West."

9

AMONG THE COLLEGES.
Harvard will have class relay swimming teams. A water-polo team will also
he organized.
The editor-in-chief of the Iowa State College paper gets three hours' credit
per term, and each of his assistants gets one hour of credit per term.
The University of Michigan holds weekly singing meetings, led by the Glee
Club, at which college songs are rehearsed. This is a hint for Hopkins rooters.
Harvard has the largest college library in the United States, having 700,000 volumes, Yale has 200,000, Columbia 133,000, Cornell 126,000. Johns
Hopkins, with 100,000 volumes, and the 300,000 of the Peabody so near, is in
the first rank.
Mr. Conried's Irving Place Theatre Company will present Goethe's "Iphigenie
auf Tauris" in New Haven on March 6th for the benefit of the Yale German
Seminary library. Soon we shall have Messrs. Nixon & Zimmerman producing, "The French Maid," or "The Girl from Maxim's" for the benefit of the
Romance department of the University.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

5

A debate has been arranged between Wellesley and Vassar colleges to take
Place May 1st at Wellesley College. This is one of the first instances of competition between two large women's colleges in any branch of student activity.
Albert J. Louney, a Harvard law student, has succeeded in translating the
Iliad into English hexameter. Both Pope and Bryant considered such a translation impossible.
'The lacrosse team of the University of Pennsylvania has received an invitation to make a tour of Canada next June and play the leading college teams of
Canada. It is not probable that the invitation will he accepted.
At the Chicago and Buffalo Expositions the college man, as such, had very
little attention paid to him. So the directors of the St. Louis Exposition have
decided to set aside an entire building for the exclusive use of the college man,
thus affording both a rallying point and an opportunity for exhibiting the work
of learning. As an educational feature alone this plan is to be commended;
but when it is considered from a college man's standpoint it is to be hailed with
Joy.

THE BALLAD OF THE BANQUET.
Imitation of Wordsworth.
I'm just a tiny college youth
And in sin seldom stray.
In paths of wisdom and of truth
I keep the narrow way.
But I'm inquisitive I must own,
I always must get next.
My curiosity is known
By secrets to be vexed.
Now when I saw a college crowd
Go in the hotel fine,
Although I am just awful proud,
I quickly got in line.
They were a crowd of college Fresh,
They were as green as grass.
I did not think they would immesh
A man from my great class.
They did not stop, they did not stare,
They did not stay a minute,
They got a bottle, I declare,
And fresh milk they put in it.
I had to drink the nasty stuff,
The bad boys made me do it.
I tried to work a great big bluff,
But they said I would rue it.
But drinking milk I did not dread,
That was not so bewilderin',
As when the bad boys laughing said
That "milk was good for children."

S has been the custom the senior editors remaining on the NEWS-LETTER
resign at Easter, and turn the paper over to the junior class. Before
handing in our official resignation we desire, on behalf of the senior
editors, to say a few words of thanks to all those who have so kindly assisted
us in our efforts to make the NEWS-LETTER a success. Student and teacher
alike has encouraged us by active contribution and discriminating criticism,
and many who were formerly high enemies to the paper have, at last, condescended to support it. Our only aim has been to bring the NEWS-LETTER into
closer contact with the men enrolled at the University, and the various changes
we have made have only been means to that end. If the interest which is excited by the arrival of the paper from the printers, on Wednesday afternoon is
a criterion we think we can modestly assert that we have gone a slight way on
the path laid out. On the junior class the burden now lies of continuing the
NEWSLETTER, and though it is a burden which, at times, is onerous, the
junior representatives now on the paper can very well uphold it. To the editors about to assume charge of the paper, we wish all the success and prosperity due them and the undertaking they represent.

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

7

HE debate which the Hopkins representatives, Messrs. Plaggemeyer and
Stone, put up at the first intercollegiate contest was so strong, and came
so near beating the trained speakers from the South that many people in
the audience were in breathless suspense awaiting the decision. North Carolina with her wealth of orators, Hopkins in her first contest; North Carolina
holding the negative side of the Trust question, and thus having the last
Speech, Hopkins working hard against this disadvantage: these antitheses
make the defeat of the Hopkins team one to be as proud of as a victory. The
most gratifying feature of the occasion was that the contest was engaged in by
undergraduates of both Universities, and not by trained law or theological
students, It is a rather striking coincidence that both of the Hopkins speakers
were men who in later years will study medicine. Next year Hopkins will
have more intercollegiate debates with colleges both North and South, and
there is no reason why we cannot give any competitor a hard fight. On one
thing in any arrangements to be made Hopkins should insist, and that is that
all contests must be engaged in by undergraduates only. The only possible
source from which we can draw debaters is the small undergraduate body, and
we should demand that the men we go up against shall be in the same class.
It would be foolish for our young undergraduates to debate with law students
or with students who devote the major part of their time to courses, which, in
the Hopkins curriculum only take up two hours a month; and for that reason
we should debate with colleges willing to send undergraduates against us, or
we should not debate at all.

HE NEWS-1,1iTT1R desires to make a suggestion to the managers of Hop-

kins athletics. Last fall the foot-ball management adopted the policy of
selling, at a moderate cost, season tickets to all the home games. This
Policy resulted successfully. Now.that spring athletics are just about to start
We would suggest to the managements of the base-ball and lacrosse teams that,
lf not conflicting with their financial arrangements, they also adopt this policy.
Everything is to be gained by such a step, and nothing can be lost, as tickets
for the individual games can also be sold. It seems to us that a consolidation
of spring athletics into one by means of a season book, admitting to all Hopkins
games in Baltimore would be a good thing, and would possibly be even better than two sets of season tickets. If such an innovation were tried, and
Proved successful, its final culmination must be a year book admitting holder to
all home games.

e

HE home base ball season begins this Friday in a game with Princeton.
So far the men have shown up so well and have put up such good work
that past records are being forgotten in congratulations for this year's
work. The best and only way for the students to support the sport, however, is
by attendance at the games, and we want to urge the presence of as many men
at the game Friday as generally attend an opening lacrosse game. Conscientiouly as the base ball lovers have worked they deserve support, and should get
it. The NRWS-LETTER hopes that the stands will be filled Friday.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

8

Z

HE Maryland Intercollegiate Athletic Association has disbanded without
much disturbance The association has accomplished what it started to
do, and with only three members its present status was not very important. Hopkins students have recently begun to care less and less for the
championship banners of the association, and at the end of the last foot-ball
season expressions of a desire for Hopkins to get out of the League were heard
on all sides. In football if a schedule can be arranged with more colleges outside of the State,—the Pennsylvania and New York colleges for instance,—
victories will mean much more to us than the Maryland Intercollegiate banner,
and defeats will have much less sting Our track and field team for the last
few years has been so far ahead of her competitors in the association that it almost had a monopoly at the association games, and the strongest teams we met
on the track were not in the League.
Though the period of usefulness for the Maryland Association is past, it
has, since its organization, been a strong factor—almost the only factor—in the
attempt to wipe out professionalism from the colleges in Maryland. To day
the former members of the Maryland Association are almost the only colleges
in Maryland which run their athletics on a clean, amateur basis. When the
League started, professionalism was the rule at all colleges in Maryland. If
the formation of the association has cleaned up athletics at a few colleges and
set an example for others to follow, it has been a benefit to athletics in this and
other States, as anything which has for its aim the promotion of true sport at
American colleges is a benefit. If some of the larger northern Universities
would be as careful about engaging with colleges of small standing who play
professionals as they are about their mutual exchange of courtesies, American
college sport would receive such an upward impetus that the small college playing professionals would be a thing of the past.

We beg to publish the following letter, and ask for answers to it.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Since the intercollegiate debate, several students at the University have
spoken about the reward that is due men who represent Hopkins in the intercollegiate college contests. They deserve some honor for their work just as
much as men on the lacrosse or foot-ball teams, and I should like to suggest to
the NEWS-LETTER that you ask for expressions of opinion on the matter from
the students and faculty. It does not seem appropriate that the same as is
bestowed on athletes should be granted the debaters, but it certainly is plain
that something parallel to the athletic "H" should be given them. They go
to the same trouble of training, the only difference being that in the case of the
debaters the season is longer; they also uphold the honor of the black and blue
against opposing colleges just as the athletic teams do. The main point is
how to reward them.
A SENIOR.

R. WILLIAM A. CASE, who for the last five years has been a postgraduate student at the Hopkins, was recently elected professor of
German and sciences at the Roanoke High School. Mr. Case was
born in Baltimore.
On the 19th of March, Dr. Jacob H. Hollander went to Washington in
response to an invitation to appear before the House of Representatives Committee on Insular Affairs, which has the Phillipine Bill under consideration.
Notwithstanding his other arduous duties, Dr. Remsen has accepted his
appointment by Mayor Hayes as a member of the School Board. Dr. Remsen
Will, as it were, succeed Dr. Gilman, who resigned a few weeks ago.
On Monday afternoon, March 17, Prof. Wood delivered a most interesting
lecture on"Recent Development in color Photography." Dr. Wood clearly
explained both the direct and indirect methods of photographing in colors, and
Showed many pictures, a few of which were made by himself, but most of
Which were sent to him by the greatest experts in color photography in the
world. Some of the pictures were remarkably life-like.
. Dr. Harry C. Jones, of the department of chemistry, has just published "The Elements of Physical Chemisty," the first systematic and comprehensive text book of physical chemistry which has been written in the English
language. This work will be used as a text-book at the Hopkins, and at many
Other colleges in the United States and Canada. Dr. Jones has for a long
time devoted his time to the study of this new science, which is really only fifteen
Years old. He has been congratulated on the successful completion of his book
by many prominent scientists, but he was particularly gratified by receiving a
congratulatory letter from Professor Oswald, of the University of Leipsic, under
Whom he at one time studied.
On March 10, the trustees held their regular monthly meeting, which had
been postponed on account of Dr. Remsen's visit to Coicago.
.
Dr. Samuel Ives Curtiss, of Chicago Seminary, who has traveled extensively
in Syria and Palestine, will deliver on April 23, a lecture on "The Deification
of Men."
"Through Mexico with the Institute of American Engineers" is the subject
of the lecture which was delivered to the Johns Hopkins Club on its field
night by Dr. William B. Clark, director of the geological department. The
lecture was well illustrated.

10

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Dr. Hollander, who is very familiar with all economic problems connected
with Baltimore, has recently expressed his opinion in the papers in favor of the
Municipal Art Society's sewerage bill as opposed to the Pentz bill. He also
has shown that Baltimore can easily stand a $72,000,000 sewerage loan.
Mr. Howard Eager, leader of the Glee Club, has recovered from his recent
attack of diphtheria.
The senior class was photographed. So was the freshman class; but there was not a long account in the newspapers of all the attendant circumstances.
Mr. E. S. Whiteman, who has recently been ill, had two landscapes in the
Art Loan Exhibition. One of these,"A Low Pasture Sunrise," has been very
highly praised. Both of these pictures were among the best exhibited by Baltimore artists.
At the annual banquet of the Harvard Club of Maryland, held at the new
Carrollton Hotel on the night of the 20th, toasts were responded to by President Remsen, Dr. Steiner and Professor Wood.
Several of the greetings received from various universities on the celebration of the 25th anniversary have been placed on exhibition in the case near the
registrar's office.
Dr. Remsen will deliver an address at the dedication of the Gayley Labatory of Chemistry and Metallurgy of Lafayette College, which will take place
on Saturday, April 5th.
Dr. Henry C. Adams, professor of Political Economy in the University of
Michigan, published an article in the Outlook of March 22nd on "Municipal
Ownership and Corrupt Politics."

THE SENIOR BANQUET.
On the evening after the intercollegiate debate the Senior Class held its
banquet at the St. James' Hotel. Mr. Williams, U. N. C. '02, was a guest of
the class, and many toasts were drunk to cement the friendship of Hopkins and
North Carolina. Mr. Lyman C. Murphy presided as toastmaster, and made the
evening very pleasant with his numerous "jokes" and witty references to the
men whom he called upon to answer toasts.
The toasts and those who answered them were:
The Class, Harvey B. Stone; Athletics, E. Palmer Bernheim; The Senate,
John G. Campbell; The Hullabaloo, Chas. A. Myers; College, William B. Hill;
Evolution, Charles Markell, Jr.; Woman, Ross M. Diggs; The Future, Sol
Strause.
Mr. Samuel Stolman, who was expected to give an entertaining lecture on
philosophy lectures was unable to be present, to the regret of his class-mates.

HE snow has melted, and the team has had a few days of out-door practice,
only to be driven back to the cage until the present cold spell will have
passed away.
In the four days of outdoor practice nothing startling has been discovered
by the coaches. As was to be expected, the old men showed up to a better advantage than at any practice heretofore. From all appearances Putts will be
back at inhome, with his partner, B. Bernheim, at outhome. First attack is
Still being filled by different men among whom are Sayler, Smith, Pearre, and
Bryan. Second attack is still open, but the chances are in favor of Bird. P.
Beruheim and Abercrombie will fill third attack and centre respectively, and
should develop some clever team work.
On the defense Tough has been playing third very credibly. As to second
defense, Blank and Custis seem to be dividing the honors between them; more
outdoor practice will, probably, before long, show the better man. Henry
Straus will once more teach our opponents how to play first defense. Behind
him, at cover, K Schmeisser is making a good showing, and with Captain
Schmeisser at point the team ought not to be afraid of too many goals against
them. The goal will be filled by either Briscoe or Pels, neither of whom has as
Yet the better of the argument.
It was really surprising to the writer, when he went to the American
League Park on Saturday last, to see two full teams out for practice. We believe this has not happened in the history of Hopkins Lacrosse before; and may
It not be the last time! Now, boys, buckle down, and perfect your team play.
Pennsylvania must be our first victim.

12

THE NEWS—LETTER.

BASE BALL.
J. I--I. U. 15. ROCK HILL 10.
ARCH 15th was very early for outdoor sport, yet the new base ball team
was favored by a warm sun, with light wind and 50° F. The game,
of course, was a preliminary trial, an experiment to test the qualities
of the different candidates, and the organization of the team. It was encouraging to note that every man was on band at the appointed hour. Whatever may
be the abilities of those composing the base ball squad, and whatever the likelihood of producing a winning team, the good faith and purpose of the men cannot be doubted.
The story of the game may be divided into two parts. For Hopkins,
Wright went in to pitch, and it was soon apparent that he was not in condition.
The balls went wild, and when they did come over the plate, the batter seemed
to be able to hit. Because of this, and because of three careless errors, Rock
Hill was prospering, and had secured 10 runs by the end of the fourth inning.
It was time for a change. Whipple went into the box, and the aspect of things
altered. In the five innings that he pitched only one safe hit was made, and
that might have been prevented by a more desperate attempt to field the ball. The
man who reached first base was put out in a beautiful double play. Whipple
struck out six men, and displayed admirable control and head work. Twice he
struck out a batter who had only three balls. If such skill can be maintained,
we need not fear for the success of the team of 1902.
Of the team itself, it may be said that it showed at first an unsteadiness not
to be wondered at in an opening game, but later played with harmony and
snap. Marine, at second base, promised to do better than formerly. His fielding and batting have improved since last year. Eliot Strouse will make a
success of short stop, and is useful for his batting, base running and "ginger."
He will improve by trying to cover more ground, and by playing more naturally. Nelson is a new man at third base. He is a hard worker and enthusiastic, and has made great improvement. He moves quickly and throws with
speed and accuracy. So far his batting has been weak, but two good hits were
his record in the game. McKnight, in left field, is a player of experience and
skill. He should strengthen the team greatly. Besides him, Ogle, Hand,
Marshall, and Crozier played in the outfield. All of them are good fielders and
batters. Gilman, at first base, did very well, but he has not yet gotten into
shape. Campbell caught well, but is not up to the best form in throwing.
Of course, all efforts are directed to producing a strong team with which to
oppose Princeton on the 28th. . By that time Constantine will be at his old
place on first, and it is probable that Wright will be in the outfield. What
showing Hopkins will make can only be conjectured, but let us hope that the
Black and Blue will be valiantly upheld. The game will be interesting, anyhow, as it brings to Baltimore the college champions of the United States, and
opens for the National Game a new era among the colleges of this city.

TRACK AND FIELD.
ANNUAL ATHLETIC CONTEST

al

OTWITHSTANDING the second-term examinations just finished, the
track and field team has kept up pretty steady training for the games
.which will be held in the cage on the evening of April 5th. Each afternoon a large squad has turned out for work, and now that Pessagno and Tootle
are again in the running our showing should be better than ever.
Hopkins will not be without a great many competitors, however, for not
only are representatives coming from Washington and Philadelphia, but the
United States Naval Academy will send up a squad to enter the field, track and
fencing events. In the latter art the middies are extremely proficient, and
several novel exhibitions are promised. Professor Zehuber has several Hopkins
men hard at work in learning how to handle the sword. Of these "Billy"
Weedon is among the most promising, and he will probably put up a very
creditable bout.
It was thought that Haverford College would send a team to compete, but
word has been received that the Quakers will not be able to come.
The officials for the games have not yet been definitely decided upon, but
every effort will be made to enlist the services of a competent corps of expePericnced men. Especial care will be given to the selection of handicappers.
. With regard to the condition of the track, also, great care will be taken.
EIghteen laps will constitute one mile, and the width will be increased to ten
feet, Each afternoon the men from the preparatory schools who expect to enter
the various events turn out, and at night the athletic clubs are given an opportunity to train. From these a great many expressions of satisfaction have been
heard in regard to the cinder track, banked at the curves. It is a great advantage over the slippery, flat track at the armory, and excellent time should be
Made on the running events.
. With the addition of the gallery, and the large seating capacity of the gymnasium and the interior of the track, ample room should be provided for the
sPectators.
Very naturally, Hopkins will enter a large squad in the contests. The list
has not yet been completed, but among those who will try to win laurels for
he black and blue will be Captain England, W. E. Hoffman, Riggs, Weedon,
Lindsay, Stone, Blanck, Pessagno, Tootle, Whipple, Lawson, Scholl, Emig,
Rosenheim, Brehm, LeCron, R. C. Hoffman, Williams, Tough and Gorwood
.
The medals which will be given as prizes have been received from the
Jeweler, and they are well worth striving for.
The arrangements are in the hands of Aubrey Pearre, chairman; Howard
Matthai, Alexander Yearly, and William Murkland. These men are being
ably assisted by Physical Director W. M. Mackdermott, who first suggested the
idea of holding regular indoor games in the Cage.
. On the night of the contests there will be large delegations present from the
various organizations entered, and it will be the duty of every Hopkins man to
turn out and show the spectators what real, genuine college yells and songs
sound like. In no other way can we gain popularity more quickly than by
Showing that we loyally support our athletic teams at the University. Let every
man be out!

THE NEWS—LETTER.
EXCLUSIVE ETHEL AND HER FRIEND.
An Incident of the Debate.

There was once a girl named Exclusive Ethel. For three generations back
her male ancestors had never been guilty of wearing detachable cuffs. This entitled Ethel to break bread with the Colonial Dames. Ethel's last name was
de Bullion. Old man de Bullion spent his time at the bank; Algernon de Bullion spent his in the club windows and in a Turkish bath. But he did not own
up to the Turkish bath.
Exclusive Ethel paid more attention to Fashion than a farmer does to a
sick shoat. While wandering on the boulevard nothing would make her step
high quicker than to pass a female person who advertised a popular brand of
perfumery.
Miss de Bullion had what the lady-novelists call a rose-bud mouth, and a
nose that came perilously near to tilting at an uncomfortable angle. But that
was nuts to Ethel; it helped her to give a mere man a glance of scorn that was
sharp enough to urge a broken-down Cab Horse into a trot.
Mr. Percival Polychrome was Exclusive Ethel's best friend. Although he
needed money you could not have paid him to have admitted that his greatgrand-mother came over from Ireland in the steerage. He was a youthful member of Ethel's set If any one took ill just before a dinner party, it was always
Mr. Percival who was Johnny-on-the-spot. He was really good at filling such
vacancies; the vacancy was hardly so noticeable when he filled in.
Now Percival had a cousin who played on the Mandolin Club at the University. The cousin was a good fellow. He had only one draw back—that
was Percival. When Percival went driving in a lady friend's victoria, he did
not notice the poor cousin. But on occasions when he met him in the Rathkeller he would permit the cousin to purchaee a sloe gin ricky for him. When
Percival heard that there was to be a debate at the University, and discovered
the select few to grace the occasion, he hied him to the cousin and exerted his
influence. The cousin gave him two tickets to pet rid of him.
This was the opportunity that Percival Polychrome had been looking for.
It would cost him nothing to take Exclusive Ethel to the function, and he
would keep up his reputation as a friend of the ladies.
Now Ethel was a stickler for style. She wore a feather boa in sections because it was too long to wear all at once She had a Kangaroo walk that would
make Dan Daly gasp with envy. If Exclusive Ethel had read in vogue that it
was proper to chew gum, she would have taken hers from underneath the dining-room table, and paralyzed the pike by chewing in public. Ethel did not
want to go to the debate before half past eight; because it was not stylish to go
early. She wanted to rustle down the aisle amidst a flutter of sighs and subdued whispers. Sne knew that she looked extremely becoming that evening.
In fact Mr. Percival Polychrome had told her so himself as he gazed into her
deep, soulful eyes. She had looked down and blushed. Ethel could do a great
deal with that blush; it was almost as great a winner as her eyes when they
were suffused with tears.
It pleased Percival that she did not want to go early, for he belonged to the
"Knights of Rest." He also.rested in the daytime. He did not like to exert
himself. It was not worth while to even play Ping-Pong. One always feels
like bathing one's self in Talcum Powder if one plays the bloody game. That
was the way he talked.
When they got to the University the doors were closed, and a horrid man
said that he would not let them in. There were other people there, but Exclusive Ethel only gave them the eye. She meant to get in or bust. The man

THE NEWS—LETTER.

15

asked her not to bust in the doorway. Ethel gave him a look of scorn; but it
did not count. The man was as hard as ever. Exclusive Ethel knew a professor who was inside. If she could a note to him all would he well. For a
quarter the man decided to take the note. Now the professor was laying for a
chance to get even with the de Bunions. It happened that old man de Bullion
had got chesty when the committee had come to him to ask him to aid the in.
stitution. So he took great pleasure in writing to Ethel that he could do nothing for her. Percival asked the man to give him his quarter back, hut the man
Pretended not to hear him. Like the ordinary people Miss de Bullion and her
Obedient escort were forced to forego the pleasure of hearing the Debate.
Exclusive Ethel blamed their tardiness on Percival.

DEBATING IN A SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY.
llE debate has been a cherished institution in the University of North
Carolina from its earliest days. It has the impulse of past achievement and
the st•mulus of tradition. But to realize its status in the university some
knowledge is necessary of two institutions that have fostered and cherished it,
the Dialectic and Philanthropic literary societies." These societies are almost coeval with the university itself, their life dating from the year 1795.
The existence of two such societies in the same college with like interests
and aims led necessarily to friendly rivalry. This has taken the form of intersociety debates. At present the "society stipulations" provide for a series of
three contests yearly, a fieshman -sophomore, a sophomore-junior, and a juniorsenior intersociety debate. Representatives for these debates are elected, but
merit, not politics, is the arbiter. The stimulus and benefit arising from this
graded system is obvious. The next step was to combine and seek a foreign
foe. In 1897 a series of three intercollegiate debates was arranged with the
conUniversity of Georgia, and the arrangement renewed in 1900 for a similar

How does this work come in touch with other lines of endeavor in the university? In several ways. First, the committee that decides these contests is

of expression, of logic, and former debaters who have been through the mill
and won their laurels. Furthermore, the speeches thus prepared are accepted
as theses by the departments they most appropriately fall under; e. g., a speech
thus made on the trust problem could be offered as a graduating thesis in the
department of economics.

they seemed to know their subject as well, and up to the last speech by the
negative they were probably in the lead. In the opinion of some people in the
audience the speeches of the two Hopkins men did not fit together as well as
those of their opponents, which may have had some effect on the decision. At
all events, our team of raw men debating against men whose training is sketched
In .the preceding article put up a fight that was creditable enough to inspire
Pride in every Hopkins son.
To be more specific, our first speaker, Harry Plaggemeyer, was, as usual,
very effective; he had with him that earnest, convincing manner that the critic
of the last inter-class debate has already noted. Plaggemeyer is so true in his
method that he would almost convince a judge if he recited one of "Mother
Goose's" rhymes. Plaggemeyer's first speech was, too, unutterably slow, and
was only redeemed by the speaker's forensic skill. His speech had point to it,
but it lacked vigor and attractiveness. Plaggemeyer seemed to feel this, and
was not nearly so effective as in the second speech, when he warmed up to his
subject and made one of the best speeches of the evening.
Mr. Stern made the first speech for the negative. Stern is not an orator,
hut he says what he has to say in a clear-cut, intelligent manner, that carries
conviction wherever it is heard. This only applies to his first address. His
second speech would only have done justice to a third-rate demagogue. It is
Incomprehensible how a man of Mr. Stern's intelligence could have written so
Poor a speech. However, Stern's splendid first speech did much to give victory
to the negative.
Stone for Hopkins was clever and, evidently, had considerable knowledge
of his subject. Both of his speeches seemed to be extemporaneous, and were,
consequently, somewhat disjointed. Stone made some of his opponent's arguments appear so absurd and self-contradictory that they did not even attempt to
answer him. Stone's rebuttal was admirable, and if any man at Hopkins has a
greater power of satire, and knows how to get at the salient points of an argument better than Stone, he has not been heard at McCoy Hall for a few years.
By far the best speaker of the evening was Williams. who closed the debate for North Carolina. His first speech fitted beautifully with his colleague's.
It was a very interesting argument on "How the Trust Promotes Foreign
Trade." His second speech, the last of the evening, was the best of the evening.
In it, Williams won the debate for North Carolina. Before that speech it
seemed to the writer that Hopkins had the better of the discussion, but after it
the judges could have only made one decision and they did.
Both Stone and Plaggemeyer worked hard and spoke well, and it is quite
Probable that with a few more weeks preparation there would have been a differ
ent story to tell. But as a gentleman who had much to do with the debate said:
"Hopkins didn't lose by much" This defeat at our first inter-collegiate debate
should not discourage us, because there was nothing discouraging in our work.
It would have been more discouraging to win a poor debate. A defeat like this
one will only nerve us on to a victory over North Carolina and other colleges,
(Columbia and Brown, probably,) next year. That is, if we have the true
Hopkins spirit."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
A TALK WITH DR. PEARSONS.

R. D. K. PEARSONS is an aged Chicago philanthropist who has
given a great deal of money to Western colleges. His opinions on
educational methods are, therefore, of some weight. They are also
rather curious, when we remember that this is the twentieth century.
Here are some extracts from an interview given by Dr. Pearsons to some
newspaper men in Chicago:
(Sfieaking of Football.)
"It's a humbug. If I had a boy going to college and he played football or
baseball I would whip him. Down with them both! They are fads and we, in
our educational practices get back to our first principles. They say football
and baseball are good exercise for muscular development; why, if you really
want to develop a boy's muscles put him to sawing wood or raising potatoes
and watch his muscles grow. I never played football or baseball.
"As for the college fads, they are bad, bad. The regular college curri
culum is the thing to follow, and when students go a chasing after this thing
and that thing they tumble over. There are too many fads, and one of the
worst is this habit of sending girls away to schools where tuition alone amounts
to several hundred dollars a year. There is no use of paying more than $2 a
week for board and $150 should carry any young man or young woman through
college for a year.
"They are through raising the kind of boys in the East that made this
country what it is, and the type of men are growing up in the West that made
New England famous 100 years ago. Eastern boys are effeminate. They are
being reared in too much luxury and have not that sturdiness that characterizes
the boy of the West."

AMONG THE COLLEGES.
Harvard will have class relay swimming teams. A water-polo team will also
he organized.
The editor-in-chief of the Iowa State College paper gets three hours' credit
per term, and each of his assistants gets one hour of credit per term.
The University of Michigan holds weekly singing meetings, led by the Glee
Club, at which college songs are rehearsed. This is a hint for Hopkins rooters.
Harvard has the largest college library in the United States, having 700,000 volumes, Yale has 200,000, Columbia 133,000, Cornell 126,000. Johns
Hopkins, with 100,000 volumes, and the 300,000 of the Peabody so near, is in
the first rank.
Mr. Conried's Irving Place Theatre Company will present Goethe's "Iphigenie
auf Tauris" in New Haven on March 6th for the benefit of the Yale German
Seminary library. Soon we shall have Messrs. Nixon & Zimmerman producing, "The French Maid," or "The Girl from Maxim's" for the benefit of the
Romance department of the University.

A debate has been arranged between Wellesley and Vassar colleges to take
Place May 1st at Wellesley College. This is one of the first instances of competition between two large women's colleges in any branch of student activity.
Albert J. Louney, a Harvard law student, has succeeded in translating the
Iliad into English hexameter. Both Pope and Bryant considered such a translation impossible.
'The lacrosse team of the University of Pennsylvania has received an invitation to make a tour of Canada next June and play the leading college teams of
Canada. It is not probable that the invitation will he accepted.
At the Chicago and Buffalo Expositions the college man, as such, had very
little attention paid to him. So the directors of the St. Louis Exposition have
decided to set aside an entire building for the exclusive use of the college man,
thus affording both a rallying point and an opportunity for exhibiting the work
of learning. As an educational feature alone this plan is to be commended;
but when it is considered from a college man's standpoint it is to be hailed with
Joy.

THE BALLAD OF THE BANQUET.
Imitation of Wordsworth.
I'm just a tiny college youth
And in sin seldom stray.
In paths of wisdom and of truth
I keep the narrow way.
But I'm inquisitive I must own,
I always must get next.
My curiosity is known
By secrets to be vexed.
Now when I saw a college crowd
Go in the hotel fine,
Although I am just awful proud,
I quickly got in line.
They were a crowd of college Fresh,
They were as green as grass.
I did not think they would immesh
A man from my great class.
They did not stop, they did not stare,
They did not stay a minute,
They got a bottle, I declare,
And fresh milk they put in it.
I had to drink the nasty stuff,
The bad boys made me do it.
I tried to work a great big bluff,
But they said I would rue it.
But drinking milk I did not dread,
That was not so bewilderin',
As when the bad boys laughing said
That "milk was good for children."

S has been the custom the senior editors remaining on the NEWS-LETTER
resign at Easter, and turn the paper over to the junior class. Before
handing in our official resignation we desire, on behalf of the senior
editors, to say a few words of thanks to all those who have so kindly assisted
us in our efforts to make the NEWS-LETTER a success. Student and teacher
alike has encouraged us by active contribution and discriminating criticism,
and many who were formerly high enemies to the paper have, at last, condescended to support it. Our only aim has been to bring the NEWS-LETTER into
closer contact with the men enrolled at the University, and the various changes
we have made have only been means to that end. If the interest which is excited by the arrival of the paper from the printers, on Wednesday afternoon is
a criterion we think we can modestly assert that we have gone a slight way on
the path laid out. On the junior class the burden now lies of continuing the
NEWSLETTER, and though it is a burden which, at times, is onerous, the
junior representatives now on the paper can very well uphold it. To the editors about to assume charge of the paper, we wish all the success and prosperity due them and the undertaking they represent.

HE debate which the Hopkins representatives, Messrs. Plaggemeyer and
Stone, put up at the first intercollegiate contest was so strong, and came
so near beating the trained speakers from the South that many people in
the audience were in breathless suspense awaiting the decision. North Carolina with her wealth of orators, Hopkins in her first contest; North Carolina
holding the negative side of the Trust question, and thus having the last
Speech, Hopkins working hard against this disadvantage: these antitheses
make the defeat of the Hopkins team one to be as proud of as a victory. The
most gratifying feature of the occasion was that the contest was engaged in by
undergraduates of both Universities, and not by trained law or theological
students, It is a rather striking coincidence that both of the Hopkins speakers
were men who in later years will study medicine. Next year Hopkins will
have more intercollegiate debates with colleges both North and South, and
there is no reason why we cannot give any competitor a hard fight. On one
thing in any arrangements to be made Hopkins should insist, and that is that
all contests must be engaged in by undergraduates only. The only possible
source from which we can draw debaters is the small undergraduate body, and
we should demand that the men we go up against shall be in the same class.
It would be foolish for our young undergraduates to debate with law students
or with students who devote the major part of their time to courses, which, in
the Hopkins curriculum only take up two hours a month; and for that reason
we should debate with colleges willing to send undergraduates against us, or
we should not debate at all.

HE NEWS-1,1iTT1R desires to make a suggestion to the managers of Hop-

kins athletics. Last fall the foot-ball management adopted the policy of
selling, at a moderate cost, season tickets to all the home games. This
Policy resulted successfully. Now.that spring athletics are just about to start
We would suggest to the managements of the base-ball and lacrosse teams that,
lf not conflicting with their financial arrangements, they also adopt this policy.
Everything is to be gained by such a step, and nothing can be lost, as tickets
for the individual games can also be sold. It seems to us that a consolidation
of spring athletics into one by means of a season book, admitting to all Hopkins
games in Baltimore would be a good thing, and would possibly be even better than two sets of season tickets. If such an innovation were tried, and
Proved successful, its final culmination must be a year book admitting holder to
all home games.

HE home base ball season begins this Friday in a game with Princeton.
So far the men have shown up so well and have put up such good work
that past records are being forgotten in congratulations for this year's
work. The best and only way for the students to support the sport, however, is
by attendance at the games, and we want to urge the presence of as many men
at the game Friday as generally attend an opening lacrosse game. Conscientiouly as the base ball lovers have worked they deserve support, and should get
it. The NRWS-LETTER hopes that the stands will be filled Friday.

HE Maryland Intercollegiate Athletic Association has disbanded without
much disturbance The association has accomplished what it started to
do, and with only three members its present status was not very important. Hopkins students have recently begun to care less and less for the
championship banners of the association, and at the end of the last foot-ball
season expressions of a desire for Hopkins to get out of the League were heard
on all sides. In football if a schedule can be arranged with more colleges outside of the State,—the Pennsylvania and New York colleges for instance,—
victories will mean much more to us than the Maryland Intercollegiate banner,
and defeats will have much less sting Our track and field team for the last
few years has been so far ahead of her competitors in the association that it almost had a monopoly at the association games, and the strongest teams we met
on the track were not in the League.
Though the period of usefulness for the Maryland Association is past, it
has, since its organization, been a strong factor—almost the only factor—in the
attempt to wipe out professionalism from the colleges in Maryland. To day
the former members of the Maryland Association are almost the only colleges
in Maryland which run their athletics on a clean, amateur basis. When the
League started, professionalism was the rule at all colleges in Maryland. If
the formation of the association has cleaned up athletics at a few colleges and
set an example for others to follow, it has been a benefit to athletics in this and
other States, as anything which has for its aim the promotion of true sport at
American colleges is a benefit. If some of the larger northern Universities
would be as careful about engaging with colleges of small standing who play
professionals as they are about their mutual exchange of courtesies, American
college sport would receive such an upward impetus that the small college playing professionals would be a thing of the past.

We beg to publish the following letter, and ask for answers to it.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Since the intercollegiate debate, several students at the University have
spoken about the reward that is due men who represent Hopkins in the intercollegiate college contests. They deserve some honor for their work just as
much as men on the lacrosse or foot-ball teams, and I should like to suggest to
the NEWS-LETTER that you ask for expressions of opinion on the matter from
the students and faculty. It does not seem appropriate that the same as is
bestowed on athletes should be granted the debaters, but it certainly is plain
that something parallel to the athletic "H" should be given them. They go
to the same trouble of training, the only difference being that in the case of the
debaters the season is longer; they also uphold the honor of the black and blue
against opposing colleges just as the athletic teams do. The main point is
how to reward them.
A SENIOR.

lecture on"Recent Development in color Photography." Dr. Wood clearly
explained both the direct and indirect methods of photographing in colors, and
Showed many pictures, a few of which were made by himself, but most of
Which were sent to him by the greatest experts in color photography in the
world. Some of the pictures were remarkably life-like.
. Dr. Harry C. Jones, of the department of chemistry, has just published "The Elements of Physical Chemisty," the first systematic and comprehensive text book of physical chemistry which has been written in the English
language. This work will be used as a text-book at the Hopkins, and at many
Other colleges in the United States and Canada. Dr. Jones has for a long
time devoted his time to the study of this new science, which is really only fifteen
Years old. He has been congratulated on the successful completion of his book
by many prominent scientists, but he was particularly gratified by receiving a
congratulatory letter from Professor Oswald, of the University of Leipsic, under
Whom he at one time studied.

with Baltimore, has recently expressed his opinion in the papers in favor of the

has shown that Baltimore can easily stand a $72,000,000 sewerage loan.
Mr. Howard Eager, leader of the Glee Club, has recovered from his recent

THE SENIOR BANQUET.
On the evening after the intercollegiate debate the Senior Class held its
banquet at the St. James' Hotel. Mr. Williams, U. N. C. '02, was a guest of
the class, and many toasts were drunk to cement the friendship of Hopkins and
North Carolina. Mr. Lyman C. Murphy presided as toastmaster, and made the
evening very pleasant with his numerous "jokes" and witty references to the
men whom he called upon to answer toasts.
The toasts and those who answered them were:
The Class, Harvey B. Stone; Athletics, E. Palmer Bernheim; The Senate,
John G. Campbell; The Hullabaloo, Chas. A. Myers; College, William B. Hill;
Evolution, Charles Markell, Jr.; Woman, Ross M. Diggs; The Future, Sol
Strause.
Mr. Samuel Stolman, who was expected to give an entertaining lecture on
philosophy lectures was unable to be present, to the regret of his class-mates.

HE snow has melted, and the team has had a few days of out-door practice,
only to be driven back to the cage until the present cold spell will have
passed away.
In the four days of outdoor practice nothing startling has been discovered
by the coaches. As was to be expected, the old men showed up to a better advantage than at any practice heretofore. From all appearances Putts will be
back at inhome, with his partner, B. Bernheim, at outhome. First attack is
Still being filled by different men among whom are Sayler, Smith, Pearre, and
Bryan. Second attack is still open, but the chances are in favor of Bird. P.
Beruheim and Abercrombie will fill third attack and centre respectively, and
should develop some clever team work.
On the defense Tough has been playing third very credibly. As to second
defense, Blank and Custis seem to be dividing the honors between them; more
outdoor practice will, probably, before long, show the better man. Henry
Straus will once more teach our opponents how to play first defense. Behind
him, at cover, K Schmeisser is making a good showing, and with Captain
Schmeisser at point the team ought not to be afraid of too many goals against
them. The goal will be filled by either Briscoe or Pels, neither of whom has as
Yet the better of the argument.
It was really surprising to the writer, when he went to the American
League Park on Saturday last, to see two full teams out for practice. We believe this has not happened in the history of Hopkins Lacrosse before; and may
It not be the last time! Now, boys, buckle down, and perfect your team play.
Pennsylvania must be our first victim.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

BASE BALL.
J. I--I. U. 15. ROCK HILL 10.
ARCH 15th was very early for outdoor sport, yet the new base ball team
was favored by a warm sun, with light wind and 50° F. The game,
of course, was a preliminary trial, an experiment to test the qualities
of the different candidates, and the organization of the team. It was encouraging to note that every man was on band at the appointed hour. Whatever may
be the abilities of those composing the base ball squad, and whatever the likelihood of producing a winning team, the good faith and purpose of the men cannot be doubted.
The story of the game may be divided into two parts. For Hopkins,
Wright went in to pitch, and it was soon apparent that he was not in condition.
The balls went wild, and when they did come over the plate, the batter seemed
to be able to hit. Because of this, and because of three careless errors, Rock
Hill was prospering, and had secured 10 runs by the end of the fourth inning.
It was time for a change. Whipple went into the box, and the aspect of things
altered. In the five innings that he pitched only one safe hit was made, and
that might have been prevented by a more desperate attempt to field the ball. The
man who reached first base was put out in a beautiful double play. Whipple
struck out six men, and displayed admirable control and head work. Twice he
struck out a batter who had only three balls. If such skill can be maintained,
we need not fear for the success of the team of 1902.
Of the team itself, it may be said that it showed at first an unsteadiness not
to be wondered at in an opening game, but later played with harmony and
snap. Marine, at second base, promised to do better than formerly. His fielding and batting have improved since last year. Eliot Strouse will make a
success of short stop, and is useful for his batting, base running and "ginger."
He will improve by trying to cover more ground, and by playing more naturally. Nelson is a new man at third base. He is a hard worker and enthusiastic, and has made great improvement. He moves quickly and throws with
speed and accuracy. So far his batting has been weak, but two good hits were
his record in the game. McKnight, in left field, is a player of experience and
skill. He should strengthen the team greatly. Besides him, Ogle, Hand,
Marshall, and Crozier played in the outfield. All of them are good fielders and
batters. Gilman, at first base, did very well, but he has not yet gotten into
shape. Campbell caught well, but is not up to the best form in throwing.
Of course, all efforts are directed to producing a strong team with which to
oppose Princeton on the 28th. . By that time Constantine will be at his old
place on first, and it is probable that Wright will be in the outfield. What
showing Hopkins will make can only be conjectured, but let us hope that the
Black and Blue will be valiantly upheld. The game will be interesting, anyhow, as it brings to Baltimore the college champions of the United States, and
opens for the National Game a new era among the colleges of this city.

TRACK AND FIELD.
ANNUAL ATHLETIC CONTEST

al

OTWITHSTANDING the second-term examinations just finished, the
track and field team has kept up pretty steady training for the games
.which will be held in the cage on the evening of April 5th. Each afternoon a large squad has turned out for work, and now that Pessagno and Tootle
are again in the running our showing should be better than ever.
Hopkins will not be without a great many competitors, however, for not
only are representatives coming from Washington and Philadelphia, but the
United States Naval Academy will send up a squad to enter the field, track and
fencing events. In the latter art the middies are extremely proficient, and
several novel exhibitions are promised. Professor Zehuber has several Hopkins
men hard at work in learning how to handle the sword. Of these "Billy"
Weedon is among the most promising, and he will probably put up a very
creditable bout.
It was thought that Haverford College would send a team to compete, but
word has been received that the Quakers will not be able to come.
The officials for the games have not yet been definitely decided upon, but
every effort will be made to enlist the services of a competent corps of expePericnced men. Especial care will be given to the selection of handicappers.
. With regard to the condition of the track, also, great care will be taken.
EIghteen laps will constitute one mile, and the width will be increased to ten
feet, Each afternoon the men from the preparatory schools who expect to enter
the various events turn out, and at night the athletic clubs are given an opportunity to train. From these a great many expressions of satisfaction have been
heard in regard to the cinder track, banked at the curves. It is a great advantage over the slippery, flat track at the armory, and excellent time should be
Made on the running events.
. With the addition of the gallery, and the large seating capacity of the gymnasium and the interior of the track, ample room should be provided for the
sPectators.
Very naturally, Hopkins will enter a large squad in the contests. The list
has not yet been completed, but among those who will try to win laurels for
he black and blue will be Captain England, W. E. Hoffman, Riggs, Weedon,
Lindsay, Stone, Blanck, Pessagno, Tootle, Whipple, Lawson, Scholl, Emig,
Rosenheim, Brehm, LeCron, R. C. Hoffman, Williams, Tough and Gorwood
.
The medals which will be given as prizes have been received from the
Jeweler, and they are well worth striving for.
The arrangements are in the hands of Aubrey Pearre, chairman; Howard
Matthai, Alexander Yearly, and William Murkland. These men are being
ably assisted by Physical Director W. M. Mackdermott, who first suggested the
idea of holding regular indoor games in the Cage.
. On the night of the contests there will be large delegations present from the
various organizations entered, and it will be the duty of every Hopkins man to
turn out and show the spectators what real, genuine college yells and songs
sound like. In no other way can we gain popularity more quickly than by
Showing that we loyally support our athletic teams at the University. Let every
man be out!

THE NEWS—LETTER.
EXCLUSIVE ETHEL AND HER FRIEND.
An Incident of the Debate.

There was once a girl named Exclusive Ethel. For three generations back
her male ancestors had never been guilty of wearing detachable cuffs. This entitled Ethel to break bread with the Colonial Dames. Ethel's last name was
de Bullion. Old man de Bullion spent his time at the bank; Algernon de Bullion spent his in the club windows and in a Turkish bath. But he did not own
up to the Turkish bath.
Exclusive Ethel paid more attention to Fashion than a farmer does to a
sick shoat. While wandering on the boulevard nothing would make her step
high quicker than to pass a female person who advertised a popular brand of
perfumery.
Miss de Bullion had what the lady-novelists call a rose-bud mouth, and a
nose that came perilously near to tilting at an uncomfortable angle. But that
was nuts to Ethel; it helped her to give a mere man a glance of scorn that was
sharp enough to urge a broken-down Cab Horse into a trot.
Mr. Percival Polychrome was Exclusive Ethel's best friend. Although he
needed money you could not have paid him to have admitted that his greatgrand-mother came over from Ireland in the steerage. He was a youthful member of Ethel's set If any one took ill just before a dinner party, it was always
Mr. Percival who was Johnny-on-the-spot. He was really good at filling such
vacancies; the vacancy was hardly so noticeable when he filled in.
Now Percival had a cousin who played on the Mandolin Club at the University. The cousin was a good fellow. He had only one draw back—that
was Percival. When Percival went driving in a lady friend's victoria, he did
not notice the poor cousin. But on occasions when he met him in the Rathkeller he would permit the cousin to purchaee a sloe gin ricky for him. When
Percival heard that there was to be a debate at the University, and discovered
the select few to grace the occasion, he hied him to the cousin and exerted his
influence. The cousin gave him two tickets to pet rid of him.
This was the opportunity that Percival Polychrome had been looking for.
It would cost him nothing to take Exclusive Ethel to the function, and he
would keep up his reputation as a friend of the ladies.
Now Ethel was a stickler for style. She wore a feather boa in sections because it was too long to wear all at once She had a Kangaroo walk that would
make Dan Daly gasp with envy. If Exclusive Ethel had read in vogue that it
was proper to chew gum, she would have taken hers from underneath the dining-room table, and paralyzed the pike by chewing in public. Ethel did not
want to go to the debate before half past eight; because it was not stylish to go
early. She wanted to rustle down the aisle amidst a flutter of sighs and subdued whispers. Sne knew that she looked extremely becoming that evening.
In fact Mr. Percival Polychrome had told her so himself as he gazed into her
deep, soulful eyes. She had looked down and blushed. Ethel could do a great
deal with that blush; it was almost as great a winner as her eyes when they
were suffused with tears.
It pleased Percival that she did not want to go early, for he belonged to the
"Knights of Rest." He also.rested in the daytime. He did not like to exert
himself. It was not worth while to even play Ping-Pong. One always feels
like bathing one's self in Talcum Powder if one plays the bloody game. That
was the way he talked.
When they got to the University the doors were closed, and a horrid man
said that he would not let them in. There were other people there, but Exclusive Ethel only gave them the eye. She meant to get in or bust. The man

asked her not to bust in the doorway. Ethel gave him a look of scorn; but it
did not count. The man was as hard as ever. Exclusive Ethel knew a professor who was inside. If she could a note to him all would he well. For a

chance to get even with the de Bunions. It happened that old man de Bullion
had got chesty when the committee had come to him to ask him to aid the in.

Pretended not to hear him. Like the ordinary people Miss de Bullion and her

Exclusive Ethel blamed their tardiness on Percival.
